comment.author: 35113154@N06
comment._content:
These are most likely Newhaven or Granton (nr Leith ) fishwives. When I was a boy in the nearby seaside/fishing town of Musselburgh in the 1950's/60's, there were still old fishwives who went around the town dressed like this as their daily dress.  A part of Musselburgh called Fisherrow was the fishing district, near the harbour.

The fishwives' dress included a black knitted shawl and a blue/white striped skirt. I can't remember the blouse arrangement ! Even today, Musselburgh hosts an annual Fishermen's Walk, a parade which is part of the annual Festival, where descendants of the now-defunct fisher families, such as the Fairnies,  parade in outfits just like the 19th Century photo above.

comment.author: 35113154@N06
comment._content: PS the baskets mentioned above as carried on the fishwives' backs, were for collecting the herring off the boats. It was a hard life and in those old days, the fishwives usually had to follow the herring fleets and be on hand to gut the fish, a excrutiating task where the ladies had to slit and de-gut the loads of herring. This caused immense pain from the sheer cold of the endless fish and often they would cut themsleves severely with the razor-sharp gutting knives and not feel the pain, as their hands were numb with cold.
